section.title: Macros of &abbrev;
section.para: The following macros are available in &abbrev;.

simplesect.title: AMPM
simplesect.para: Description: Typically used together with the ${HOUR12} macro, ${AMPM} returns the period of the day: AM for hours before mid day and PM for hours after mid day. In reference to a 24-hour clock format, AM is between 00:00-12:00 and PM is between 12:00-24:00. 12AM is midnight. Available in &abbrev; 3.2&abbrev; 3.4 and later.

simplesect.title: BSDTAG
simplesect.para: Description: Facility/priority information in the format used by the FreeBSD syslogd: a priority number followed by a letter that indicates the facility. The priority number can range from 0 to 7. The facility letter can range from A to Y, where A corresponds to facility number zero (LOG_KERN), B corresponds to facility 1 (LOG_USER), and so on.

simplesect.title: Custom macros
simplesect.para: Description: CSV parsers and pattern databases can also define macros from the content of the messages, for example, a pattern database rule can extract the username from a login message and create a macro that references the username. For details on using custom macros created with CSV parsers and pattern databases, see and , respectively.

simplesect.title: FACILITY
simplesect.para: Description: The name of the facility (for example, kern) that sent the message.

simplesect.title: FACILITY_NUM
simplesect.para: Description: The numerical code of the facility (for example, 0) that sent the message.

simplesect.title: FULLHOST
simplesect.para: Description: The full FQDN of the host name chain (without trimming chained hosts), including the domain name.

simplesect.title: FULLHOST_FROM
simplesect.para: Description: FQDN of the host that sent the message to syslog-ng as resolved by syslog-ng using DNS. If the message traverses several hosts, this is the last host in the chain.
The &abbrev; application uses the following procedure to determine the value of the $FULLHOST_FROM macro:

listitem.para: The &abbrev; application takes the IP address of the host sending the message.

If the use-dns() option is enabled, &abbrev; attempts to resolve the IP address to a hostname. If it succeeds, the returned hostname will be the value of the $FULLHOST_FROM macro. This value will be the FQDN of the host if the use-fqdn() option is enabled, but only the hostname if use-fqdn() is disabled.
If the use-dns() option is disabled, or the address resolution fails, the ${FULLHOST_FROM} macro will return the IP address of the sender host.

simplesect.title: HOUR12, R_HOUR12, S_HOUR12
simplesect.para: Description: The hour of day the message was sent in 12-hour clock format. See also the ${AMPM} macro. 12AM is midnight. Available in &abbrev; 3.2&abbrev; 3.4 and later.

simplesect.title: HOST
simplesect.para: Description: The name of the source host where the message originates from.

listitem.para: If the message traverses several hosts and the chain-hostnames() option is on, the first host in the chain is used.

If the keep-hostname() option is disabled (keep-hostname(no)), the value of the $HOST macro will be the DNS hostname of the host that sent the message to &abbrev; (that is, the DNS hostname of the last hop). In this case the $HOST and $HOST_FROM macros will have the same value.

If the keep-hostname() option is enabled (keep-hostname(yes)), the value of the $HOST macro will be the hostname retrieved from the log message. That way the name of the original sender host can be used, even if there are log relays between the sender and the server.

simplesect.title: HOST_FROM
simplesect.para: Description: Name of the host that sent the message to syslog-ng, as resolved by syslog-ng using DNS. If the message traverses several hosts, this is the last host in the chain.

simplesect.title: ISODATE, R_ISODATE, S_ISODATE
simplesect.para: Description: Date of the message in the ISO 8601 compatible standard timestamp format (yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ss+-ZONE), for example: 2006-06-13T15:58:00.123+01:00. If possible, it is recommended to use ${ISODATE} for timestamping. Note that syslog-ng can produce fractions of a second (for example milliseconds) in the timestamp by using the frac-digits() global or per-destination option.

simplesect.title: LEVEL_NUM
simplesect.para: Description: The priority (also called severity) of the message, represented as a numeric value, for example, 3. For the textual representation of this value, use the ${LEVEL} macro. See for details.

simplesect.title: MONTH_ABBREV, R_MONTH_ABBREV, S_MONTH_ABBREV
simplesect.para: Description: The English abbreviation of the month name (3 letters).

simplesect.title: MONTH_NAME, R_MONTH_NAME, S_MONTH_NAME
simplesect.para: Description: The English name of the month name.

simplesect.title: MONTH_WEEK, R_MONTH_WEEK, S_MONTH_WEEK
simplesect.para: Description: The number of the week in the given month (0-5). The week with numerical value 1 is the first week containing a Monday. The days of month before the first Monday are considered week 0. For example, if a 31-day month begins on a Sunday, then the 1st of the month is week 0, and the end of the month (the 30th and 31st) is week 5.

simplesect.title: MSEC, R_MSEC, S_MSEC
simplesect.para: Description: The millisecond the message was sent.
Available in &abbrev; version 4 F23.4 and later.

simplesect.title: MSG or MESSAGE
simplesect.para: Description: Text contents of the log message without the program name and pid. Note that this has changed in syslog-ng version 3.0; in earlier versions this macro included the program name and the pid. In syslog-ng 3.0, the ${MSG} macro became equivalent with the ${MSGONLY} macro. The program name and the pid together are available in the ${MSGHDR} macro.

simplesect.title: MSGID
simplesect.para: Description: A string specifying the type of the message in IETF-syslog (RFC5424-formatted) messages. For example, a firewall might use the ${MSGID} "TCPIN" for incoming TCP traffic and the ${MSGID} "TCPOUT" for outgoing TCP traffic. By default, &abbrev; does not specify this value, but uses a dash (-) character instead. If an incoming message includes the ${MSGID} value, it is retained and relayed without modification.

simplesect.title: MSGONLY
simplesect.para: Description: Message contents without the program name or pid.

simplesect.title: PID
simplesect.para: Description: The PID of the program sending the message.

simplesect.title: PRI
simplesect.para: Description: The priority and facility encoded as a 2 or 3 digit decimal number as it is present in syslog messages.

simplesect.title: PRIORITY or LEVEL
simplesect.para: Description: The priority (also called severity) of the message, for example, error. For the textual representation of this value, use the ${LEVEL} macro. See for details.

simplesect.title: PROGRAM
simplesect.para: Description: The name of the program sending the message. Note that the content of the ${PROGRAM} variable may not be completely trusted as it is provided by the client program that constructed the message.

simplesect.title: RCPTID
simplesect.para: Description: This is disabled by default due to performance issues. To enable it, add the next option to the global options: use-rcptid(yes);. For details, see also . A unique ID for messages generated at reception time on the receiving host. It facilitates defining relationships between messages that are potentially distributed to different files on the same host, or different hosts.

example.title: Using ${RCPTID} macro
example.para: Using the following template statement in the configuration: template demo_template { template("${DATE} ${HOST} ${PROG}: ${MSG} ID:${RCPTID}\n"); }; the outgoing message will be the following: <133>Feb 25 14:09:07 webserver syslogd: restart. ID:1.

simplesect.title: SDATA, .SDATA.SDID.SDNAME, STRUCTURED_DATA
simplesect.para: Description: The syslog-ng application automatically parses the STRUCTURED-DATA part of IETF-syslog messages, which can be referenced in macros. The ${SDATA} macro references the entire STRUCTURED-DATA part of the message, while structured data elements can be referenced using the ${.SDATA.SDID.SDNAME} macro.Available only in &product; 4.0 and later.

note.para: When using STRUCTURED-DATA macros, consider the following:

listitem.para: When referencing an element of the structured data, the macro must begin with the dot (.) character. For example, ${.SDATA.timeQuality.isSynced}.
The SDID and SDNAME parts of the macro names are case sensitive: ${.SDATA.timeQuality.isSynced} is not the same as ${.SDATA.TIMEQUALITY.ISSYNCED}.

example.title: Using SDATA macros
example.para: For example, if a log message contains the following structured data: [exampleSDID@0 iut="3" eventSource="Application" eventID="1011"][examplePriority@0 class="high"] you can use macros like: ${.SDATA.exampleSDID@0.eventSource} — this would return the Application string in this case.

simplesect.title: SEQNUM
simplesect.para: Description: The sequence number of the message is a unique identifier of the message between the end-points. The syslog-ng client calculates this number when processing a new message from a local source; it is not calculated for relayed messages. The sequence number increases for every message, and is not lost even if syslog-ng is reloaded. The sequence number starts again from 0 when &abbrev; is restarted. The sequence number is a part of every message that uses the new IETF-syslog protocol (${.SDATA.meta.sequenceId}), and can be added to BSD-syslog messages using this macro.
If &abbrev; receives a message via the IETF-syslog protocol that includes a sequence ID, this ID is automatically available in the ${SEQNUM} macro.

&abbrev; versions 3.23.4 and later versions store the sequence number from Cisco IOS log messages using the extended timestamp format in this macro. If this message is then forwarded using the IETF-syslog protocol, &abbrev; includes the sequence number received from the Cisco device in the ${.SDATA.meta.sequenceId} part of the message.

note.para: To enable sequence numbering of log messages on Cisco devices, use the following command on the device (available in IOS 10.0 and later): service sequence-numbers.
For details, see Cisco IOS Configuration Fundamentals and Network Management Command Reference.

simplesect.title: SOURCE
simplesect.para: Description: The identifier of the source statement in the &abbrev; configuration file that received the message. For example, if &abbrev; received the log message from the source s_local { internal(); }; source statement, the value of the ${SOURCE} macro is s_local. This macro is mainly useful for debugging and troubleshooting purposes.

simplesect.title: SOURCEIP
simplesect.para: Description: IP address of the host that sent the message to syslog-ng. (That is, the IP address of the host in the ${FULLHOST_FROM} macro.) Please note that when a message traverses several relays, this macro contains the IP of the last relay.

simplesect.title: STAMP, R_STAMP, S_STAMP
simplesect.para: Description: A timestamp formatted according to the ts-format() global or per-destination option.

simplesect.title: SYSUPTIME
simplesect.para: Description: The time elapsed since the computer running &abbrev; has booted. If this data is not available, the macro contains the time elapsed since &abbrev; was started. The value of this macro is an integer containing the time in 1/100th of the second.
Available in &abbrev; version 4 F13.4 and later.

simplesect.title: TAG
simplesect.para: Description: The priority and facility encoded as a 2 digit hexadecimal number.

simplesect.title: TAGS
simplesect.para: Description: A comma-separated list of the tags assigned to the message. Available only in &product; 3.2 and later.

note.para: Note that the tags are not part of the log message and are not automatically transferred from a client to the server. For example, if a client uses a pattern database to tag the messages, the tags are not transferred to the server. A way of transferring the tags is to explicitly add them to the log messages using a template and the ${TAGS} macro, or to add them to the structured metadata part of messages when using the IETF-syslog message format.
When sent as structured metadata, it is possible to reference to the list of tags on the central server, and for example, to add them to a database column.

simplesect.title: USEC, R_USEC, S_USEC
simplesect.para: Description: The microsecond the message was sent.
Available in &abbrev; version 4 F23.4 and later.

simplesect.title: WEEK_ABBREV, R_WEEK_ABBREV, S_WEEK_ABBREV
simplesect.para: Description: The 3-letter English abbreviation of the name of the day the message was sent, for example Thu.

simplesect.title: WEEK_DAY, R_WEEK_DAY, S_WEEK_DAY
simplesect.para: Description: The day of the week as a numerical value (1-7).

simplesect.title: WEEKDAY, R_WEEKDAY, S_WEEKDAY
simplesect.para: Description: These macros are deprecated, use ${WEEK_ABBREV}, ${R_WEEK_ABBREV}, ${S_WEEK_ABBREV} instead. The 3-letter name of the day of week the message was sent, for example Thu.

simplesect.title: WEEK_DAY_NAME, R_WEEK_DAY_NAME, S_WEEK_DAY_NAME
simplesect.para: Description: The English name of the day.
